SEARCH
Module org.klojang.jdbc
Package org.klojang.jdbc

Interface SQLSession

public sealed interface SQLSession

A SQLSession allows you to provide values for template variables within an SQL template. Once you have set all template variables, you can obtain a SQLStatement from the SQLSession and use it to set (a.k.a. "bind") the named parameters within the SQL. The difference between template variables and named parameters is explained in the comments for the SQL interface. Since the SQLSession implementation obtained via SQL.simple()) does not allow for template variables, you have no choice but to retrieve a SQLStatement from it straight away. If the SQL does not contain any named parameters, you may also call execute() on the SQLSession, without going through the creation of a SQLStatement.

SQLSession instances are meant to be throw-away objects that should, in principle, not survive the method in which they are created.

  • Method Details

    • set

      default SQLSession set(String varName, Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the specified template variable to the specified value. Only use this method if you know and trust the origin of the provided value. The value will not be escaped or quoted. Preferably use setValue() or setIdentifier() to prevent SQL injection. If the value is an array or collection, it will be "imploded" to a string, using "," (comma) to separate the elements in the array or collection. This method will throw an UnsupportedOperationException for simple SQL sessions since these are not based on Klojang Templates.
      Parameters:
      varName - the name of the template variable
      value - the value to set the variable to
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method
      See Also:
      • Template
      • RenderSession.set(String, Object)
      • ArrayMethods.implode(Object[])
      • CollectionMethods.implode(Collection)

    • setValue

      default SQLSession setValue(String varName, Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the specified template variable to the escaped and quoted version of the specified value. Use this method if you do not know or trust the origin of the value to prevent SQL injection. If the value is an array or Collection, it will be "imploded" to a string, using a comma to separate the elements in the array or collection, and using quoteValue() to escape and quote each element separately. Otherwise this method is equivalent to set(varName, quoteValue(value)).
      Parameters:
      varName - the name of the template variable
      value - the value to set the variable to
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method
      See Also:
      • quoteValue(Object)

    • setArray

      default SQLSession setArray(String varName, Object... values) throws UnsupportedOperationException

      Convenience method, equivalent to setValue(varName, values). Can be used to elegantly populate a SQL IN clause with an arbitrary number of values: 

      
 SQL sql = SQL.template("SELECT * FROM AIRPORT WHERE NAME IN(~%names%)";
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   List<Airport> airports =  sql.session(con)
       .setArray("names", "London Heathrow", "Chicago O'Hare")
       .prepareQuery()
       .getExtractor()
       .extractAll();
 }

      This will execute the following SQL: 

      
 SELECT * FROM AIRPORT WHERE NAME IN('London Heathrow','Chicago O''Hare')
      Parameters:
      varName - the name of the template variable
      values - an array, which will be "imploded" to a String, using a comma to separate the array elements, and using quoteValue() to escape and quote the array elements
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method
      See Also:
      • quoteValue(Object)

    • setArray

      default SQLSession setArray(String varName, int... values) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Convenience method, equivalent to setValue(varName, values).
      Parameters:
      varName - the name of the template variable
      values - an array, which will be "imploded" to a String, using a comma to separate the array elements
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method

    • setIdentifier

      default SQLSession setIdentifier(String varName, String identifier) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the specified template variable to the escaped and quoted version of the specified identifier (e.g. a column name or table name).
      Parameters:
      varName - the name of the template variable
      identifier - the identifier to substitute the variable with
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method
      See Also:

    • setNested

      default SQLSession setNested(String path, Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException

      Sets a variable in a nested template within the SQL skeleton to the specified value. If the value is an array or collection, it will be "imploded" to a string, using "," (comma) to separate the elements in the array or collection. This method is only supported for SQL skeletons. When calling this method on a SQLSession obtained via SQL.simple() or SQL.template(), this method will throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

      NB Nested templates in general are only supported in SQL skeletons. The are not supported in regular SQL templates.

      Parameters:
      path - the path to the variable within the SQL skeleton
      value - the value to set the variable to
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was not obtained via SQL.skeleton()

    • setNestedValue

      default SQLSession setNestedValue(String path, Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException

      Sets a variable in a nested template within the SQL skeleton to the escaped and quoted version of the specified value. If the value is an array or collection, it will be "imploded" to a string, using "," (comma) to separate the elements in the array or collection, and using quoteValue() to escape and quote each element separately. This method is only supported for SQL skeletons. When calling this method on a SQLSession obtained via SQL.simple() or SQL.template(), this method will throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

      NB Nested templates in general are only supported in SQL skeletons. The are not supported in regular SQL templates. 

      
 String sql = """
     SELECT * FROM EMPLOYEE
     ~%%begin:whereClause%
      WHERE FIRST_NAME LIKE ~%searchPhrase% OR LAST_NAME LIKE ~%searchPhrase%
     ~%%end:whereClause%
     """;
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   SQLSession session = SQL.skeleton(sql).session(con);
   if(searchPhrase != null) {
     session.setNestedValue("whereClause.searchPhrase", '%' + searchPhrase + '%');
   }
   try(SQLQuery query = session.prepareQuery()) {
     return query.getExtractor(Employee.class).extractAll();
   }
 }

      Note that, by default, nested templates are not rendered. They remain invisible unless you do something that makes them become visible. In this case, setting a variable within the nested template forces its entire contents to become visible. Alternatively, you can call enable(String) to force the contents of a nested template to become visible.

      Parameters:
      path - the path to the variable within the SQL skeleton
      value - the value to set the variable to
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was not obtained via SQL.skeleton()

    • setNestedIdentifier

      default SQLSession setNestedIdentifier(String path, String identifier) throws UnsupportedOperationException

      Sets a variable in a nested template within the SQL skeleton to the escaped and quoted version of the specified identifier (e.g. a column name or table name). This method is only supported for SQL skeletons. When calling this method on a SQLSession obtained via SQL.simple() or SQL.template(), this method will throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

      NB Nested templates in general are only supported in SQL skeletons. The are not supported in regular SQL templates.

      Parameters:
      path - the path to the variable within the SQL skeleton
      identifier - the identifier to substitute the variable with
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was not obtained via SQL.skeleton()

    • enable

      default SQLSession enable(String nestedTemplate) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Enables the contents of the specified nested template. That is, the contents of the specified nested template will be rendered. By default, nested templates remain invisible unless you do something that makes them become visible. This method is only supported for SQL skeletons. When calling this method on a SQLSession obtained via SQL.simple() or SQL.template(), this method will throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

      NB Nested templates in general are only supported in SQL skeletons. The are not supported in regular SQL templates. 

      
 String sql = """
     SELECT * FROM EMPLOYEE
     ~%%begin:whereClause%
      WHERE FIRST_NAME LIKE :searchPhrase OR LAST_NAME LIKE :searchPhrase
     ~%%end:whereClause%
     """;
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   SQLSession session = SQL.skeleton(sql).session(con);
   if(searchPhrase != null) {
     session.enable("whereClause");
   }
   try(SQLQuery query = session.prepareQuery()) {
     if(searchPhrase != null) {
       query.bind("searchPhrase", searchPhrase);
     }
     return query.getExtractor(Employee.class).extractAll();
   }
 }
      Parameters:
      nestedTemplate - the nested template within the SQL skeleton to enable
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was not obtained via SQL.skeleton()
      See Also:
      • RenderSession.enable(String...)

    • setOrderBy

      default SQLSession setOrderBy(String sortColumn) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the sort column of the ORDER BY clause within a SQL template. This presumes and requires that the template contains a template variable named "orderBy". This is a convenience method facilitating a common use case for template variables: to parametrize the sort column within the ORDER BY clause. It is equivalent to calling setIdentifier("orderBy", sortColumn). 
      
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   List<Person> lastNames = SQL.template("SELECT * FROM PERSON ORDER BY ~%orderBy%")
       .session(con)
       .setOrderBy("LAST_NAME")
       .prepareQuery(con)
       .getExtractor(Person.class)
       .extractAll();
 }
      Parameters:
      sortColumn - the column to sort on
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method

    • setOrderBy

      default SQLSession setOrderBy(String sortColumn, boolean isDescending) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      Sets the sort column and sort order of the ORDER BY clause within a SQL template. This presumes and requires that the template contains a template variable named "orderBy". This is a convenience method facilitating a common use case for template variables: to parametrize the sort column and sort order within the ORDER BY clause. 
      
 SQL sql = SQL.template("SELECT LAST_NAME FROM EMPLOYEE ORDER BY ~%orderBy%");
 try(Connection con = ...) {
   // Sort in descending order of salary
   List<String> lastNames = sql.session(con).setOrderBy("SALARY", true).prepareQuery().firstColumn();
 }
      Parameters:
      sortColumn - the column to sort on
      isDescending - whether to sort in descending order. If true, the "sortOrder" variable in the SQL template will be set to "DESC", else to "ASC".
      Returns:
      this SQLSession instance
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method

    • quoteValue

      default String quoteValue(Object value) throws UnsupportedOperationException

      Returns a properly escaped and quoted string. More precisely:

      • If the value is null, the literal string "NULL" (without the quotes) is returned.
      • If the value is a Number, a Boolean, or a SQLExpression, the value is returned as-is. That is, toString() will be called on the value, but the resulting string will not be quoted.
      • Otherwise toString() is called on the value, and the resulting string is escaped and quoted according to the quoting rules of the target database.

      Use this method if you do not know or trust the origin of the value to prevent SQL injection.

      Parameters:
      value - the value to be escaped and quoted
      Returns:
      the escaped and quoted value
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method
      See Also:
      • Statement.enquoteLiteral(String)
      • Quoter.quoteValue(Object)

    • sqlFunction

      default SQLExpression sqlFunction(String name, Object... args) throws UnsupportedOperationException

      Generates a SQL function call in which each of the function arguments is escaped and quoted using the quoteValue() method. If you do not want this to happen for a particular argument, because it is an identifier (a column name) rather than a literal value, wrap it in a SQLExpression again: 

      
 SQLExpression column = SQL.expression(session.quoteIdentifier("LAST_NAME"));
 sqlFunction("CONCAT", "Dear Mr./Ms. ", column, ","));

      NB This example is just to illustrate the point, but is of course rather silly in practice. You can see here what is being concatenated, and you can see that nothing needs escaping, and that there is no risk of SQL injection, so you might as well simply have written: "CONCAT('Dear Mr./Ms. ', LAST_NAME, ',')"

      Parameters:
      name - the name of the function, like "SUBSTRING" or "CONCAT". Note that the function name is itself not escaped or quoted. Therefore, with SQL injection in mind, be wary of this being a dynamically generated value.
      args - the function arguments. Each of the provided arguments will pass through quoteValue(Object).
      Returns:
      a SQLExpression representing a SQL function call
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method

    • quoteIdentifier

      default String quoteIdentifier(String identifier) throws UnsupportedOperationException
      If necessary, quotes the specified identifier (e.g. a column name or table name) according to the quoting rules of the target database. Use this method if the identifier is passed in from outside your program to prevent SQL injection.
      Parameters:
      identifier - the identifier to quote
      Returns:
      the quoted identifier
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - in case this SQLSession was obtained via the SQL.simple() method
      See Also:
      • Statement.enquoteIdentifier(String, boolean)
      • Quoter.quoteIdentifier(String)

    • execute

      int execute()
      Executes the SQL. You can call this method either if the SQL is completely static, or if you have set all template variables and the SQL does not contain any named parameters. If the SQL does contain named parameters, you must first bind them using a SQLStatement obtained from the SQLSession.
      Returns:
      the number of inserted, updated, or deleted rows, if applicable; -1 otherwise

    • prepareQuery

      SQLQuery prepareQuery()
      Returns a SQLQuery instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters and then execute the query.
      Returns:
      a SQLQuery instance

    • prepareInsert

      default SQLInsert prepareInsert()
      Returns a SQLInsert instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters and then execute the INSERT statement. Auto-generated keys will be made available to the client.
      Returns:
      a SQLInsert instance

    • prepareInsert

      SQLInsert prepareInsert(boolean retrieveKeys)
      Returns a SQLInsert instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters and then execute the INSERT statement.
      Parameters:
      retrieveKeys - whether to retrieve the keys that were generated by the database
      Returns:
      a SQLInsert instance

    • prepareUpdate

      SQLUpdate prepareUpdate()
      Returns a SQLUpdate instance that allows you to provide values for named parameters and then execute the UPDATE or DELETE statement.
      Returns:
      a SQLUpdate instance
